sentences.sentence: In the middle of all my work, it happened that, looking through( 逐一查看 ) my things, I found a little bag, which had been filled with corn.
The corn seemed to have been eaten by the rats.
I shook out the bag, on one side of my shelter( 住所 ), under a rock.
Soon after doing so, the rains began.
About a month after, I saw a few shoots( 嫩芽 ) of something green growing out of the ground.
I was astonished( 吃惊的 ), when I saw about ten or twelve shoots( 嫩芽 ) of green corn growing there.
I was astonished( 吃惊的 ) and confused( 疑惑的 ).
I had until now acted upon( 按照...行事 ) no religious foundation at all.
But after I saw corn grow there, I began to wonder if God had by a miracle( 奇迹 ) caused His grain to grow, without any help of seed sown( 播种 ).
I saw nearby some other green shoots( 嫩芽 ), which turned out to be rice.
Believing that there was more in the place, I went all over that part of the island.
I searched in every corner to look for more of it, but I could not find any.
At last, it occurred to( 突然想到 ) my thought, that I shook a bag of chickens’ feed( 饲料 ) out in that place, and then my wonder began to decrease( 减小 ).
I must admit that my religious thankfulness to God began to decrease( 减少 ) too, upon discovering that all this was a natural thing.
I carefully saved this corn, in its season, which was about the end of June.
Saving up every grain, I decided to sow( 播种 ) the seeds again, hoping in time to have enough to supply me with bread.
But it was not till the fourth year that I could allow myself any grain of this corn to eat, and even then only sparingly.
But to return to my journal( 日记 ).
I worked very hard these three or four months to get my wall done. The 14th of April I closed it up.
I now entered my shelter( 住所 ) by a ladder, so that there might be no sign on the outside that someone was living there.
April 16.—The very next day after this wall was finished, I almost lost all my work at once, and had myself killed.
It happened like this: As I was busy on the inside, just at the entrance into my cave, I was terribly frightened.
All of a sudden( 突然 ) I found the earth come crashing down from the roof of my cave.
Two of the posts I had set up in the cave broke in a frightful manner.
I ran forward to my ladder, and got over my wall for fear of the rocks from the hill, which I expected might roll down upon me.
I had no sooner stepped outside, than I plainly saw that it was a terrible earthquake.
I was so much amazed( 惊讶 ) by the earthquake, having never felt anything like it, that I stood still as a statue.
I thought of nothing then but the hill falling upon my tent and all my supplies, and burying all at once.
After the shock was over, I had not courage enough to go over my wall again, for fear of being buried alive.
I sat still upon the ground, not knowing what to do.
While I sat like this, the air grew gray and cloudy, as if it would rain.
Soon after that, the wind increased little by little, so that in less than half an hour it became a hurricane( 飓风 ).
The trees were torn up by the roots, and it was a terrible storm.
This lasted about three hours, and then began to decrease( 减小 ).
The rain was so violent that my tent was almost beaten down with it.
I was forced to go into my cave, though very much afraid and uneasy, for fear it should fall on my head.
After I had been in my cave for some time, and no more shocks of the earthquake followed, I began to feel calmer.
It continued raining all that night and most of the next day, so that I could not go outside.
I spent the two next days, the 19th and 20th of April, in planning where and how to move my shelter( 住所 ).
However, I realized that I would need a long time to do this.
I decided to stay where I was, till I had built a camp for myself.
I decided to hurry up and build a wall first, and set my tent up in it when it was finished. This was the 21st.
April 22.—The next morning I began to consider how to put this plan into action, but I did not know what to do about my tools.
I had three large axes( 斧子 ), but they had all grown dull( 钝的 ).
Though I had a grindstone( 磨石 ), I could not turn it, and grind my tools at the same time.
At last I found a way, using a wheel and string( 线 ), to turn it with my foot.
This machine took me a full week’s work to bring it to perfection( 使完善 ).
April 28, 29.—These two whole days I took up in sharpening( 使变得锋利 ) my tools, my machine for turning my grindstone( 磨石 ) performing very well.
April 30.—Having noticed that I had eaten most of my bread, I reduced myself to one biscuit-cake a day, which was depressing( 使人沮丧的 ).
May 1.—In the morning, looking towards the remains of the ship, I thought it seemed to lie higher out of the water than it used to do.
I found a barrel( 桶 ) which had been driven on shore, and discovered it was a barrel( 桶 ) of gunpowder( 火药 ).
Going farther out upon the sands, I tried to get as near as I could to the ship, to look for more.
When I came down to the ship, I found it strangely moved.
The sand was thrown so high on one side that I could now walk right up to the ship.
I was surprised by this at first, but soon concluded( 推断 ) it must have been done by the earthquake.
By this violence new sections of the ship had been broken open, and many things came daily on shore.
This completely shifted( 改变 ) my thoughts from the plan of moving my shelter( 住所 ).
I was busy searching for a way into the ship.
I found nothing was to be expected of that kind, for all the inside of the ship was choked( 塞满 ) up with sand.
However, I decided to pull the ship to pieces as much as I could, hoping that what I could get from it would be of some use or other to me.
I continued this work every day until the 15th of June, except for the time necessary to get food.
I took wood and iron, enough to build a good boat, if I had known how.
June 16.—Going down to the sea-side, I found a large tortoise( 乌龟 ) or turtle.
This was the first one I had seen.
Had I been on the other side of the island, I might have had hundreds of them every day, as I found later.
I spent the following day in cooking the turtle.
June 18.—Rained all day, and I stayed inside. I thought at this time the rain felt cold, and I was somewhat chilly( 寒冷的 ).
June 19.—Very ill, and shaking, as if the weather had been cold.
June 20.—No rest all night. Violent pains in my head, and feverish.
June 21.—Very ill, and frightened almost to death to be sick, and with no help.
Prayed to God, for the first time since the storm off Hull.
June 22.—A little better, but in terrible fear of sickness.
June 23.—Very bad again. Cold and shaking, and then a violent headache.
June 24.—Much better.
June 25.—A very violent fever. Hot and cold fits( 阵发 ), and sweating.
June 26.—Better. Having nothing to eat, I took my gun, but found myself very weak.
However, I killed a she-goat, and with much difficulty got it home.
June 27.—The fever was again so violent that I lay in bed all day, and neither ate nor drank.
I prayed to God again, but was light-headed( 头晕目眩的 ).
I did not know what to say, so I only lay and cried: “Lord, look upon me! Lord, pity me! Lord, have mercy( 仁慈 ) upon me!”
I suppose I did nothing else for two or three hours, until I fell asleep. While asleep I had a terrible dream,—

article_info.previous: 昨天我们读到Robinson记录的在岛上的生活日记。
article_info.share_words: In the middle of all my work, it happened that, looking through my things, I found a little bag, which had been filled with corn.

question.cn: 当Robinson看到地里长出幼苗，他怎么想的？
question.en: What did Robinson think when he saw the shoots growing from the ground?

options.cn: 他觉得是上帝在帮助他。
options.en: He thought God was helping him.

options.cn: 他立马就知道是散落的谷物长出来的。
options.en: He knew immediately that they grew because of the dropped corns.

options.cn: 他觉得一定是有人居住在这个岛上。
options.en: He thought there must be someone living on the island.

analysis: 文中说：“I had until now acted upon no religious foundation at all. But after I saw corn grow there, I began to wonder if God had by a miracle caused His grain to grow, without any help of seed sown.”所以选A。

question.cn: 墙建好之后，Robinson怎么进入他的住所？
question.en: How did Robinson enter his shelter after finishing the wall?

options.en: From a window on the roof.

analysis: 文中说：“I worked very hard these three or four months to get my wall done. The 14th of April I closed it up. I now entered my shelter by a ladder...”所以选C。

question.cn: 当土从 Robinson的洞穴的顶上掉下来时，发生什么了？
question.en: What happened when the earth came crashing down from the roof of Robinson's cave?

options.cn: 出现了一头凶猛的狮子。

analysis: 文中说：“I had no sooner stepped outside, than I plainly saw that it was a terrible earthquake.”所以选C。

question.en: What was the weather like after the earthquake?

analysis: 文中说：“The wind increased little by little, so that in less than half an hour it became a hurricane.” “It continued raining all that night and most of the next day. . . ”所以选B。

question.en: What was wrong with Robinson in June?

options.en: He was attacked by wild animals.
He was cut by the ax.

analysis: 文中说：“June 19.—Very ill, and shaking, as if the weather had been cold. June 23.—Very bad again. Cold and shaking, and then a violent headache. June 25.—A very violent fever. Hot and cold fits, and sweating.”所以选B。

share_title: 100天读完4本英文书，今天是第52天
